A lake is a paleoenvironment that represents an ancient, relatively large, standing body of water, typically freshwater or brackish, enclosed by land, that is characterized by lacustrine sedimentation, including microbialites and other carbonate precipitates, within a continental setting.

The Phanerozoic is a geological eon that represents the current and most recent interval of Earth's history, spanning from approximately 541 million years ago to the present. It is characterized by the widespread appearance and diversification of complex, multicellular life forms, particularly those with hard parts, which are abundantly preserved in the fossil record.

The Cretaceous is a geological period and chronostratigraphic system that spans from approximately 145 to 66 million years ago, marking the final period of the Mesozoic Era. It is characterized by the deposition of significant carbonate successions, including those forming the prolific Pre-Salt reservoirs in the South Atlantic.

A coquina is a type of bioclastic sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of whole or fragmented shells of bivalve mollusks, often with a minor matrix. In the Brazilian Pre-Salt, these rocks are typically lacustrine in origin and constitute significant carbonate reservoirs.
Barite is a mineral that is composed of barium sulfate (BaSO4) and is characterized by its high specific gravity, typically around 4.5.

3-brsa-1172-rjs is a well that is uniquely identified by the ANP code 3-BRSA-1172-RJS, drilled by Petrobras in the Santos Basin offshore Brazil for hydrocarbon exploration and production, often targeting Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

The Jurassic Period is a geological period that spans from approximately 201.3 to 145 million years ago. Silt is a clastic sediment particle that is characterized by a grain size finer than sand and coarser than clay, typically ranging from 1/256 mm to 1/16 mm (4 to 8 phi) on the Wentworth scale.

Albian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents the youngest interval of the Early Cretaceous epoch, spanning the time between the Aptian and Cenomanian stages.

The Pleistocene is a geological epoch that represents the first and longer of the two epochs of the Quaternary Period, spanning from approximately 2.58 million years ago to 11,700 years ago, and is characterized by significant global climatic fluctuations, including repeated glacial and interglacial cycles.

Vugular porosity is a type of secondary pore structure that is characterized by the presence of vugs, which are open, irregular cavities typically larger than interparticle pores and often formed by dissolution.

Micrite is a microcrystalline carbonate component that consists predominantly of calcite crystals less than 4 micrometers in diameter, forming the fine-grained matrix of limestones and often originating from the breakdown of skeletal material, direct precipitation, or microbial activity.

Neocomian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest part of the Early Cretaceous epoch. It encompasses the Berriasian, Valanginian, and Hauterivian stages, spanning from approximately 145 to 133 million years ago.
Halite is an evaporite rock that is primarily composed of the mineral sodium chloride (NaCl), typically forming extensive bedded deposits.

Faulting is a geological structure that is a brittle fracture or zone of fractures in rock along which there has been significant relative displacement of the rock masses on either side. It results from brittle deformation and can compartmentalize reservoirs or provide pathways for fluid migration.
Aptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that encompasses the rock succession deposited during the Aptian Age, representing a subdivision of the Lower Cretaceous Series.

The Barra Velha Formation is a lithostratigraphic unit that consists predominantly of lacustrine microbial carbonates, including stromatolites, thrombolites, and oncolites, deposited during the rift-to-sag transition phase of the South Atlantic opening.

Shrubstone is a microbialite rock that is characterized by a branching, shrub-like growth morphology, formed by the in-situ precipitation of carbonate minerals mediated by microbial communities.

The Santos Basin is a large offshore sedimentary basin that is located along the southeastern Brazilian continental margin, known for its significant hydrocarbon accumulations, particularly the prolific Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs formed during the rifting and opening of the South Atlantic.

The Paraná Basin is a large intracratonic sedimentary basin that is located in the central-eastern part of South America, primarily within Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Argentina. It is characterized by a thick succession of Paleozoic to Mesozoic sedimentary and volcanic rocks. This basin is well-known for its extensive basaltic lava flows of the Serra Geral Formation and significant coal deposits.
Limestones are sedimentary rocks that are predominantly composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), primarily formed from the accumulation of biogenic remains or by chemical precipitation.

The Campos Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore the southeastern Brazilian continental margin, representing one of Brazil's most prolific petroleum provinces. A grainstone is a carbonate rock that is characterized by being grain-supported, containing less than 10% mud matrix, and typically having its intergranular pores filled by sparry calcite cement.
Ostracods are fossil microcrustaceans that are characterized by a bivalved carapace and are widely used as biostratigraphic and paleoenvironmental indicators in sedimentary successions.
A calcimudstone is a carbonate rock that is mud-supported, containing less than 10% allochems, and primarily composed of micrite.

Galena is a mineral that is a lead sulfide (PbS) with an isometric crystal system. It typically exhibits a metallic luster, lead-gray color, and perfect cubic cleavage. Galena is the principal ore of lead and is commonly found in hydrothermal veins and sedimentary deposits.

The Paleozoic is a geological era that spans from approximately 541 to 252.2 million years ago, following the Neoproterozoic and preceding the Mesozoic. A siltite is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of silt-sized clastic particles, typically ranging from 0.004 to 0.0625 mm in diameter, and is intermediate in grain size between sandstone and mudstone.

The Devonian is a geological period and chronostratigraphic system that spans from approximately 419.2 to 358.9 million years ago. It is the fourth period of the Paleozoic Era, succeeding the Silurian and preceding the Carboniferous. This interval is characterized by the significant diversification of fish, earning it the moniker "Age of Fish," and the initial widespread colonization of land by plants and arthropods.
Holkerian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents a subdivision of the Visean Stage within the Mississippian Subperiod of the Carboniferous Period.
Valanginian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a subdivision of the Early Cretaceous Series, spanning from approximately 139.8 to 132.9 million years ago.
A mudstone is a sedimentary rock that is composed predominantly of mud-sized particles (silt and clay) and lacks fissility.

Silt is a clastic sediment particle that has a grain size finer than sand and coarser than clay. It typically ranges from 1/256 mm to 1/16 mm (4 to 8 phi) on the Wentworth scale, and is found as unconsolidated grains.

Bivalves are a type of fossilized mollusk that represents the preserved remains or traces of an aquatic invertebrate characterized by a body enclosed within two hinged shells (valves).

The Quaternary is a geological period that represents the most recent interval of Earth's history, spanning from 2.58 million years ago to the present day. Silica is a mineral that is composed of silicon dioxide (SiO2), occurring in various crystalline and amorphous forms, such as quartz, chalcedony, and opal.
Faulting is a geological structure that consists of a brittle fracture or a zone of fractures in rock along which there has been observable relative displacement of the rock masses on opposite sides.

Deltas are paleoenvironments that represent depositional systems formed at the mouth of a river where it discharges clastic sediments into a standing body of water, characterized by the progradation of sedimentary facies. A mound is a carbonate buildup that forms a positive topographic relief on the seafloor, primarily composed of microbialites or other biogenic components, and often constitutes a significant reservoir facies in the Pre-Salt.

The Pelotas Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore southern Brazil and Uruguay, formed during the Mesozoic breakup of Gondwana, and characterized by a thick rift-drift sedimentary package with potential for hydrocarbon accumulation.

Mollusks are a diverse phylum of invertebrate animals that are characterized by a soft, unsegmented body, typically enclosed in a calcareous shell, and whose fossilized remains are common in marine and freshwater sedimentary rocks, including the carbonate reservoirs of the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

The Cambrian is a geological period that represents the first period of the Paleozoic Era, spanning from approximately 541 to 485.4 million years ago. It is characterized by the "Cambrian Explosion," a rapid diversification of most major animal phyla.

Basalts are mafic volcanic rocks that are typically fine-grained and dark-colored, forming from the rapid cooling of lava at or near the Earth's surface, often associated with extensional tectonic settings and continental rifting.

Vugular is a type of physical structure within a rock that is characterized by the presence of vugs, which are discrete, equant to irregular, commonly oversized pores formed by dissolution, often larger than interparticle pores. Anhydrite is an evaporite rock that is primarily composed of the mineral anhydrite (CaSO4). It forms through the precipitation of calcium sulfate from evaporating seawater or hypersaline brines, commonly occurring in evaporite sequences and as a diagenetic product.

Arenites are clastic sedimentary rocks that are characterized by a grain size predominantly within the sand range (0.0625 to 2 mm).

Muscovite is a phyllosilicate mineral that belongs to the mica group, characterized by its perfect basal cleavage and flexible, elastic sheets. It is a potassium aluminum silicate hydroxide (KAl₂(AlSi₃O₁₀)(OH)₂) commonly found in igneous, metamorphic, and detrital sedimentary rocks.
A grain is a discrete particle that constitutes the fundamental building block of a rock, typically comprising mineral crystals, rock fragments, or biogenic components.

The Carboniferous is a chronostratigraphic unit that spans from approximately 358.9 to 298.9 million years ago, following the Devonian and preceding the Permian periods, and is globally recognized for its extensive coal swamp formation and the diversification of terrestrial vertebrates and plants.

A carbonate mound is a type of rock accumulation that is primarily composed of carbonate minerals, often formed by microbial activity (e.g., stromatolites, thrombolites) and early diagenetic cementation. A floatstone is a carbonate rock that is characterized by having more than 10% of its volume composed of grains larger than 2 mm, which are supported by a finer-grained matrix and do not touch each other.

A siliciclastic rock is a type of sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of silicate minerals derived from the physical weathering and erosion of pre-existing rocks, which are then transported, deposited, and lithified.

Evaporites are a type of sedimentary rock that forms from the precipitation of minerals from an aqueous solution, typically seawater or saline lake water, due to the evaporation of the solvent.

Tuffs are volcaniclastic rocks that are formed by the lithification of volcanic ash and other pyroclastic fragments ejected during explosive volcanic eruptions.

Mud is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of clay and silt-sized particles, typically formed in low-energy depositional environments.

A contact is a surface or zone that separates two distinct geological bodies or units, such as different rock types, stratigraphic layers, or structural domains.

Stones are fragments of rock that are naturally occurring, typically ranging in size from pebbles to cobbles, and are formed through the breakdown of larger rock masses by geological processes such as weathering and erosion.
The Jurassic is a geological period that constitutes the middle division of the Mesozoic Era, spanning from approximately 201.3 to 145 million years ago.

Feldspar is a group of tectosilicate minerals that are the most abundant minerals in the Earth's crust, characterized by their framework structure of silica and alumina tetrahedra, and containing varying amounts of potassium, sodium, or calcium.
Santonian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents a division of the Late Cretaceous epoch, spanning the time interval between the Coniacian and the Campanian stages.

The Campanian is a geological age that represents a subdivision of the Late Cretaceous Epoch. It spans from approximately 83.6 to 72.1 million years ago. This chronostratigraphic unit follows the Santonian and precedes the Maastrichtian.

Travertine is a terrestrial carbonate rock that forms by the rapid precipitation of calcium carbonate minerals, primarily calcite, from supersaturated meteoric waters at ambient or elevated temperatures, often exhibiting distinctive layered, porous, or banded textures.

Gases are a type of earth fluid that exist in a gaseous state under reservoir conditions, characterized by low viscosity and compressibility, and are typically composed of light hydrocarbon molecules and non-hydrocarbon components.

Ilyocypris is a genus of ostracod that represents a bivalved microcrustacean fossil commonly found in lacustrine deposits, serving as a key paleoenvironmental indicator for freshwater to brackish conditions in the Brazilian Pre-Salt succession.

Alagoas is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a specific geological age within the Early Cretaceous, corresponding to the Aptian stage. It is characterized by the deposition of the main sag-phase carbonate reservoirs in the Brazilian Pre-Salt basins.

Alagoas is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a specific geological age within the Early Cretaceous, corresponding to the Aptian stage. It is characterized by the deposition of the main sag-phase carbonate reservoirs in the Brazilian Pre-Salt basins.
A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids, or organic matter, that forms a significant part of the Earth's crust.

Strontium is an alkaline earth metal that is a chemical element commonly incorporated into the crystal lattice of various minerals, particularly carbonates and sulfates, often serving as a proxy for paleoenvironmental conditions and diagenetic processes.
Paleocene-Eocene is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the geological time interval spanning from the beginning of the Paleocene epoch to the end of the Eocene epoch.

Gravel is an unconsolidated clastic sediment that consists of rock fragments, mineral grains, or bioclastic material. It is characterized by a grain size larger than sand, with individual particles typically exceeding 2 mm in diameter.

An aeolian paleoenvironment is a paleoenvironment that is characterized by depositional and erosional processes dominated by wind activity, typically resulting in the formation of dune fields, sand sheets, and interdune deposits in arid or semi-arid continental settings.

Rochas carbonáticas são rochas sedimentares que são compostas predominantemente por minerais carbonáticos, como calcita e dolomita, e que se formam pela acumulação de material biogênico ou precipitação química de carbonatos.

A mound is a carbonate structure that is a positive topographic feature, formed by the in-situ accumulation of carbonate material, often of microbial or biogenic origin, in lacustrine or marine environments.

3-BRSA-1343-RJS is a well that was drilled by Petrobras in the offshore Rio de Janeiro state, identified by the sequential number 1343, representing a specific drilling operation or sidetrack within a well cluster.

3-BRSA-1345-RJS is a well that is an official identifier assigned by the Brazilian National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (ANP) to a specific bore drilled by Petrobras (BRSA) in the state of Rio de Janeiro (RJS), representing the third well in its respective drilling campaign or block.

3-BRSA-1183-RJS is a well that represents a specific bore drilled into the Earth's subsurface for exploration or production of hydrocarbons. Aptian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents a division of the Early Cretaceous epoch, succeeding the Barremian and preceding the Albian stages, and spanning from approximately 125.0 to 113.0 million years ago.

Anhydrite is an evaporite rock that is primarily composed of the mineral anhydrite (CaSO4). It forms through the precipitation of calcium sulfate from evaporating seawater or hypersaline brines, commonly occurring in evaporite sequences and as a diagenetic product.

Faults are geological structures that are brittle fractures in rock along which there has been significant relative displacement of the rock masses on opposing sides. They are fundamental controls on fluid migration, trap formation, and reservoir compartmentalization within sedimentary basins.

A siltite is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of silt-sized clastic particles, typically ranging from 0.004 to 0.0625 mm in diameter, and is intermediate in grain size between sandstone and mudstone.
A calcarenite is a limestone that is primarily composed of sand-sized (0.0625 to 2 mm) carbonate grains.

A charophyte is a fossilized green alga that produces distinctive calcified reproductive structures known as gyrogonites. These gyrogonites are commonly preserved in lacustrine and brackish water carbonate deposits, serving as important biostratigraphic markers for non-marine environments, including those of the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

Algae is a fossil that represents the preserved remains or traces of photosynthetic eukaryotic organisms, often unicellular or simple multicellular forms, which played a significant role in the formation of carbonate rocks, particularly in the Brazilian Pre-Salt reservoirs.
A gyrogonite is a fossilized reproductive structure that represents the calcified oogonium of a charophyte alga.

Grainstones-rudstones are carbonate rocks that exhibit a grain-supported fabric, containing less than 10% mud matrix, and are often characterized by a significant proportion of grains larger than 2 mm.

Neocomian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest part of the Early Cretaceous epoch. It encompasses the Berriasian, Valanginian, and Hauterivian stages, spanning from approximately 145 to 133 million years ago.
Eo-Aptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that designates the earliest interval of the Aptian stage, a subdivision of the Early Cretaceous epoch.

Neo-Aptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the upper sub-stage of the Aptian Stage within the Early Cretaceous Epoch, marking a critical period in the Brazilian Pre-Salt for the transition from sag-phase carbonate deposition to widespread evaporite precipitation.

Sylvite is a mineral that is a naturally occurring potassium chloride (KCl), crystallizing in the isometric system. It is a common evaporite mineral, often found in marine and lacustrine salt deposits, and is a primary ore of potassium.
Neogene is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a geological period within the Cenozoic Era, spanning from approximately 23.03 million years ago to 2.58 million years ago.
A diamictite is a sedimentary rock that is characterized by very poor sorting and a wide range of clast sizes, from clay to boulders, supported within a finer-grained matrix.

Mound-shaped is a descriptive term that characterizes a physical structure exhibiting a convex, isolated, and generally rounded or domal profile, often forming a topographic high relative to its surroundings.

The Miocene is a geological epoch that represents the first epoch of the Neogene Period and the fourth epoch of the Cenozoic Era. It spans from approximately 23.03 to 5.333 million years ago, characterized by significant global cooling and the diversification of mammals.

Serravallian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a global subdivision of geological time within the Middle Miocene epoch. It spans from approximately 13.82 to 11.63 million years ago, following the Langhian and preceding the Tortonian stages.
A diamictite is a type of sedimentary rock that is characterized by its poor sorting, containing a wide range of clast sizes from clay to boulders, set within a muddy or sandy matrix.

A dinoflagellate is a unicellular planktonic protist that typically possesses two flagella and often produces resistant organic cysts (dinocysts) that are preserved as microfossils in sedimentary rocks.

The Taranaki Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore and onshore the west coast of New Zealand's North Island, representing the country's primary hydrocarbon province with Mesozoic to Cenozoic sedimentary fill and significant gas and oil accumulations.

Espirito Santo basins are a series of marginal sedimentary basins that are located along the southeastern Brazilian continental margin, formed during the Mesozoic rifting and Cenozoic sag phases of the South Atlantic opening. They extend from the state of Espírito Santo northward and are significant for hydrocarbon exploration. These basins contain both post-rift and pre-salt plays, making them key targets for oil and gas production.
Campo de Bonito is an oil and gas field that is located in the Santos Basin, offshore Brazil, and is characterized by its high-quality Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs, producing light oil.

A Bacia de Campos is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore the southeastern coast of Brazil, representing one of the most prolific oil and gas provinces in the country. It is characterized by significant Pre-Salt carbonate and Post-Salt clastic reservoirs, formed during the rifting and opening of the South Atlantic Ocean.

The Neogene is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a geological period and system within the Cenozoic Era. It spans from approximately 23.03 to 2.58 million years ago. This unit follows the Paleogene Period and precedes the Quaternary Period.

The Paleogene is a chronostratigraphic unit that constitutes the earliest period of the Cenozoic Era. It spans from approximately 66 to 23 million years ago, following the Cretaceous Period and preceding the Neogene Period. This interval is marked by the diversification of mammals and significant global cooling trends.

A cyanobacteria coccoid is a fossil microorganism that represents the preserved remains of spherical or ovoid-shaped cyanobacteria, which are photosynthetic prokaryotes often found in microbialites like stromatolites, providing evidence of early life and paleoenvironmental conditions in carbonate systems.

Fossilized cyanobacteria mats are a preserved biogenic sedimentary structure that formed from the layered growth of photosynthetic prokaryotes, primarily cyanobacteria, which trapped and bound sediment particles, often resulting in laminated microbialites such as stromatolites.

Botryoids are a type of fossilized microbial carbonate precipitate that exhibits a characteristic spherical to grape-like morphology, often forming aggregates, and is common in ancient lacustrine and marine environments.
Quartzite is a metamorphic rock that is predominantly composed of quartz, formed through the metamorphism of sandstone, and is characterized by its high hardness and resistance to weathering.
Schist is a non-consolidated detrital material that consists of rock fragments, typically platy and rich in mica, derived from the weathering and erosion of a schistose metamorphic rock.

A fluvial-to-alluvial paleoenvironment is a depositional system characterized by the transition and interaction between riverine (fluvial) processes and sediment accumulation in unconfined, often fan-shaped (alluvial) settings, typically occurring along basin margins or in areas of significant topographic relief.

A mollusk shell is a biomineralized fossil that constitutes the hard, external protective covering secreted by a mollusk. These calcified or aragonitic structures are preserved in the geological record, often forming significant components within carbonate reservoirs.

Chert is a cryptocrystalline variety of quartz (SiO2) that is characterized by its hardness, conchoidal fracture, and typically occurs as nodules, concretions, or beds within sedimentary rocks. It often forms through the diagenetic replacement of carbonate minerals or the precipitation of biogenic silica from silica-rich fluids.
Structures are geological configurations of rock units that result from deformation processes, such as faulting, folding, or fracturing, which control fluid flow and hydrocarbon accumulation.

Anhydrites are evaporite rocks that are predominantly composed of the mineral anhydrite (CaSO4) and form through the precipitation of calcium sulfate from evaporating brines, often in arid or restricted marine environments.

The Benguela Basin is a sedimentary basin that developed along the passive continental margin of southwestern Africa, offshore Angola and Namibia, following the rifting and opening of the South Atlantic Ocean. It is characterized by thick syn-rift and post-rift sequences, including significant pre-salt carbonate and evaporite deposits, which hold substantial hydrocarbon exploration potential.

The Cambrian is a geological period that represents the first period of the Paleozoic Era, spanning from approximately 541 to 485.4 million years ago. It is characterized by the "Cambrian Explosion," a rapid diversification event where most major animal phyla first appeared in the fossil record.
The Berriasian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest stage of the Early Cretaceous epoch, spanning approximately from 145.0 to 139.8 million years ago.

The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located on the Brazilian equatorial margin, formed during the Gondwana breakup, and is a prolific petroleum province characterized by significant post-rift and pre-salt hydrocarbon accumulations.

A scarp is a topographic break that is characterized by a steep, linear slope or cliff, formed by differential vertical displacement along a fault or by erosional processes acting on rocks of varying resistance.
A fracture is a geological discontinuity that forms in a rock mass due to brittle deformation, resulting in a loss of cohesion across a planar or curviplanar surface.

Borborema is a fossil that represents an early life form, such as a microbial mat or a simple multicellular organism, preserved within the Precambrian to early Paleozoic sedimentary successions associated with the Borborema Province of Northeast Brazil.

The Aptian-Albian is a chronostratigraphic interval that encompasses two consecutive stages of the Cretaceous Period, spanning from approximately 125 to 100.5 million years ago, and is critical for the Brazilian Pre-Salt as it marks the post-rift sag phase characterized by the deposition of thick evaporite sequences and subsequent early post-salt carbonate and siliciclastic sediments.

A Bacia do Espírito Santo is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore the southeastern coast of Brazil, extending from the state of Espírito Santo. It originated during the Mesozoic rifting of Gondwana and is characterized by a thick succession of syn-rift, sag, and drift sediments, which host significant hydrocarbon accumulations.

"Planktonic" is a descriptive term for organisms that lived in the water column, drifting passively with currents. These organisms, when preserved as fossils, are crucial for biostratigraphic correlation and paleoenvironmental reconstructions in marine and lacustrine settings.

A collapse is a geological structure that results from the downward displacement of overlying strata into an underlying void, typically formed by the dissolution of soluble rocks or the failure of a cavern roof.

A scar is a geological feature that is characterized by a surface depression or irregular topography, formed by the localized removal of material through processes such as dissolution, collapse, or erosion.

The Cenozoic is a geological era that spans from approximately 66 million years ago to the present day. It is characterized by the diversification of mammals and the formation of modern continental configurations.

Buracica is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a specific time interval within the Early Cretaceous, characterized by the initial syn-rift lacustrine deposition in the Brazilian marginal basins.
A ridge is an elongated topographic high within a paleoenvironment that influences depositional patterns and is typically formed by structural uplift, differential erosion, or biogenic accretion.
A discordance is a geological surface that represents a significant break in the stratigraphic record, where younger sedimentary layers lie non-parallel upon older, eroded or tilted strata.
Oil is a naturally occurring fluid that is a complex mixture of hydrocarbons, predominantly in liquid phase, found within porous and permeable subsurface geological formations.

Ostracodes are a group of small bivalved crustaceans that are preserved as microfossils, characterized by a calcified, hinged carapace enclosing the body. They are abundant in both marine and freshwater sedimentary rocks, serving as key biostratigraphic markers and paleoenvironmental indicators, particularly in the context of lacustrine and marine carbonate systems like the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

The Eoproterozoic is a geological era that represents the earliest subdivision of the Proterozoic Eon, spanning from approximately 2500 to 1600 million years ago, and is characterized by the Great Oxidation Event and the assembly of the supercontinent Columbia.

The Espírito Santo Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore the Brazilian states of Espírito Santo and southern Bahia, forming part of the Brazilian passive margin. It is characterized by a thick sedimentary infill, including significant Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs, and is a prolific oil and gas province.

Mollusks are a diverse phylum of invertebrate animals that are characterized by a soft, unsegmented body, typically enclosed in a calcareous shell, and whose fossilized remains are common in marine and freshwater sedimentary rocks, including the carbonate reservoirs of the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

Charophytes are fossilized remains of freshwater green algae that are characterized by calcified reproductive structures called gyrogonites. They are significant biostratigraphic markers in lacustrine carbonate successions, including those of the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

Bivalves are a class of marine and freshwater mollusks that are characterized by a shell consisting of two hinged valves, and are frequently preserved as fossils in sedimentary rocks, serving as key paleoenvironmental indicators in carbonate successions like the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

A mold is a type of fossil that is an impression of the external or internal surface of an organism or its trace, formed when the original organic material has dissolved or decayed away, leaving a void in the surrounding sediment.
A peloid is a carbonate grain that is typically ovoid to spherical, microcrystalline, and lacks internal structure.

Cracks are a type of physical structure that represents a planar or irregular discontinuity within a rock mass, formed by tensional or shear stresses leading to a loss of cohesion. In reservoir geology, they can significantly impact permeability and porosity, especially in carbonate systems like the Pre-Salt.

Muscovite is a phyllosilicate mineral that belongs to the mica group, characterized by its perfect basal cleavage and flexible, elastic sheets. It is a potassium aluminum silicate hydroxide (KAl₂(AlSi₃O₁₀)(OH)₂) commonly found in igneous, metamorphic, and detrital sedimentary rocks.
Celestine is a mineral that is a strontium sulfate (SrSO4), typically forming as an evaporite in sedimentary rocks, often associated with limestones, dolomites, gypsum, and anhydrite.
Sparites are carbonate rocks that are characterized by a sparry calcite or dolomite cement filling the intergranular pore spaces between grains.

Cataclastic texture is a rock texture that results from brittle deformation involving fracturing, crushing, and grinding (comminution) of pre-existing mineral grains, typically without significant crystal plastic deformation, and is characterized by angular fragments of varying sizes within a finer-grained matrix.
Dolostones are sedimentary rocks that are composed of more than 50% of the mineral dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), typically formed through the diagenetic alteration of pre-existing limestones.

Grupo Lagoa Feia is a lithostratigraphic unit that comprises a succession of Aptian lacustrine deposits, predominantly evaporites (halite, anhydrite) and microbial carbonates, representing the main evaporitic phase of the Brazilian Pre-Salt succession.

An oceanic paleoenvironment is a paleoenvironment that represents the depositional conditions and biological communities characteristic of the open ocean, beyond the continental shelf and slope. It is typically characterized by deep-water sedimentation, pelagic organisms, and low energy conditions, often associated with abyssal plains or oceanic ridges.
Plio-Pleistocene is a chronostratigraphic unit that comprises the rock strata deposited during the geological time interval spanning the Pliocene and Pleistocene epochs.
The Mesoproterozoic is a geological era that constitutes the middle division of the Proterozoic Eon, spanning the time interval from 1600 to 1000 million years ago.
Silcrete is a duricrust that is a hardened layer of surficial sediments or weathered rock, cemented by silica (SiO2).

The Mesozoic is a geological era that spans from approximately 252 to 66 million years ago, encompassing the Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous periods, and is critical for the development of the South Atlantic rift system and the deposition of Pre-Salt lacustrine carbonates.

Kerolite is a rock that is predominantly composed of the hydrated magnesium silicate mineral kerolite, characterized by its talc-like properties and often found as an alteration product in magnesium-rich environments.

A carbonate is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of carbonate minerals, such as calcite (CaCO3) or dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), and typically forms from the accumulation of biogenic material or chemical precipitation in marine or lacustrine environments.

The Santos Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore the southeastern coast of Brazil, formed during the Mesozoic rifting and opening of the South Atlantic Ocean. It is characterized by a thick sedimentary infill, including prolific Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs, making it a major hydrocarbon province for Brazil.

Aptian-aged is a geological age that represents a chronostratigraphic unit within the Early Cretaceous Epoch, spanning approximately from 125.0 to 113.0 million years ago. It is characterized by the deposition of significant carbonate successions, including the major lacustrine and marine-influenced Pre-Salt reservoirs of the Brazilian continental margin.

Cenomanian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents the oldest interval of the Late Cretaceous Epoch. It spans from approximately 100.5 to 93.9 million years ago, following the Albian and preceding the Turonian stages.

Maastrichtian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents the uppermost division of the Late Cretaceous epoch, spanning from approximately 72.1 to 66.0 million years ago and immediately preceding the Paleocene Danian stage.

Precambrian is a geological supereon that represents the earliest and longest interval of Earth's history, spanning from the planet's formation approximately 4.6 billion years ago to the beginning of the Cambrian Period about 541 million years ago.

A miliolid is a biogenic mineral component that is composed of calcium carbonate and represents the skeletal remains (test) of a miliolid foraminifer, commonly found as a constituent of carbonate sediments and rocks.

Gypsum is a mineral that is a hydrated calcium sulfate (CaSO₄·2H₂O) and commonly forms as an evaporite in restricted marine or lacustrine environments. It is characterized by its relative softness and often occurs in association with halite and anhydrite.
Barremian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents a division of the Early Cretaceous epoch, spanning the time interval between the end of the Hauterivian and the beginning of the Aptian.

Grupo Lagoa Feia is a lithostratigraphic unit that comprises a succession of Aptian lacustrine deposits, predominantly evaporites (halite, anhydrite) and microbial carbonates, representing the main evaporitic phase of the Brazilian Pre-Salt succession.

Feldspars are a group of tectosilicate minerals that constitute the most abundant minerals in the Earth's crust, characterized by their framework structure of silica and alumina tetrahedra, and typically containing calcium, sodium, or potassium. They are essential components of many igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks, including those found as detrital grains or diagenetic alterations within the Brazilian Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.
A framestone is a carbonate rock that is characterized by an in-situ rigid skeletal framework of organisms that grew and bound sediment during deposition.
A bindstone is a carbonate rock that is characterized by organisms that actively bind and stabilize sediment particles during deposition, forming a rigid framework.
A sparstone is a carbonate rock that is characterized by a grain-supported fabric where the intergranular pore space is filled with sparry calcite cement.

Tufa is a porous carbonate rock that forms by the precipitation of calcium carbonate from ambient temperature freshwater, typically in springs, lakes, or rivers, often exhibiting a spongy or vesicular texture.
Lutites are sedimentary rocks that are composed predominantly of silt and clay-sized particles.

The Gabon Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located along the passive margin of West Africa, extending from onshore Gabon into its offshore waters, and is a prolific petroleum province characterized by syn-rift and post-rift hydrocarbon plays, including significant pre-salt carbonate reservoirs.

SB-A1 is an exploration well that was drilled in the Santos Basin, offshore Brazil, and is recognized as a pioneering well that confirmed significant hydrocarbon accumulations within the Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

Wackestones and packstones are carbonate rocks that are classified by Dunham's scheme, where wackestones are mud-supported with greater than 10% allochems, and packstones are grain-supported with greater than 10% allochems but still contain significant mud.

Mud limestones are a type of carbonate sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of carbonate mud (micrite) and characterized by a mud-supported fabric. They typically correspond to mudstones or wackestones in Dunham's classification and commonly form in low-energy depositional environments.
Framestones are a type of boundstone that is characterized by a rigid framework built by in-situ organisms, which act as primary framework builders.
A shell is a hard, protective outer layer that was secreted by a marine or freshwater invertebrate animal, such as a mollusk or brachiopod, and is preserved as a fossil within sedimentary rocks.
Pre-Aptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the geological time interval preceding the Aptian stage of the Early Cretaceous.

The Barremian Age is a geological age that represents a specific interval of the Early Cretaceous epoch, spanning from approximately 129.4 to 125.0 million years ago, and is characterized by distinct biostratigraphic markers and associated rock successions.

A fluvial-deltaic paleoenvironment is a depositional environment that is characterized by the interaction of riverine (fluvial) and marine (deltaic) processes, typically occurring at the interface where a river enters a standing body of water, leading to the accumulation of sediments.

Barremian Upper Aratu is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a specific time interval within the Barremian stage of the Early Cretaceous, corresponding to the deposition of the upper part of the Aratu Formation in the Brazilian marginal basins, preceding the main Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.
Marls are a sedimentary rock that is composed of a mixture of clay minerals and calcium carbonate, typically with proportions of each ranging from 35% to 65%.

Candona centroimpressa is a species of fossil ostracod that serves as a key biostratigraphic marker for the Aptian lacustrine successions of the Brazilian Pre-Salt, characterized by its non-marine affinity and distinctive carapace morphology.

Cyprideis frugosa is a species of ostracod microfossil that is characterized by a robust, often pitted or nodose carapace, and serves as a significant biostratigraphic marker for brackish to freshwater lacustrine environments, particularly within the sag and rift sequences of the Brazilian Pre-Salt.
Gastropods are a type of fossil mollusk that are characterized by a univalve, typically spirally coiled shell, or are preserved as internal molds or imprints within sedimentary rocks.

Coquina carbonates are a type of carbonate rock that is primarily composed of poorly cemented, sand- to gravel-sized shell fragments and other bioclastic debris, typically formed in high-energy lacustrine or shallow marine environments, and often characterized by high porosity and permeability.
Barremian is a chronostratigraphic stage that represents a division of the Early Cretaceous epoch, spanning the time interval between the end of the Hauterivian and the beginning of the Aptian.

Karstified rock is a carbonate rock that has undergone significant dissolution by acidic waters, resulting in the development of secondary porosity and permeability features such as vugs, caves, and conduits.
Clay is an unconsolidated sediment that is composed predominantly of particles with a diameter less than 1/256 mm (4 micrometers), exhibiting plasticity when wet and hardening upon drying.

The Toarcian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a geological age within the Early Jurassic epoch. It spans from approximately 182.7 to 174.1 million years ago, succeeding the Pliensbachian and preceding the Aalenian stages.

The Campos Basin is a passive margin sedimentary basin that is located offshore southeastern Brazil, formed during the Mesozoic rifting and Cenozoic sag phases of the South Atlantic opening. It is a prolific hydrocarbon province, characterized by significant conventional and deep-water Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

The Santos Formation is a lithostratigraphic unit that comprises a thick succession of siliciclastic rocks, predominantly shales and sandstones, deposited during the post-rift sag phase in the Santos Basin, offshore Brazil. It unconformably overlies the Pre-Salt carbonate succession and is characterized by its regional extent and distinct seismic signature.

The Campos Formation is a lithostratigraphic unit that comprises a succession of lacustrine carbonate rocks, including microbialites, deposited during the Aptian in the Campos Basin, Brazilian Pre-Salt. It constitutes a significant reservoir unit for hydrocarbons.
The Palaeoproterozoic is a geological eon that represents the earliest subdivision of the Proterozoic Eon, spanning the time interval from 2500 to 1600 million years ago.

The Namibe Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore Angola and Namibia, forming part of the passive continental margin of the South Atlantic. It comprises syn-rift and post-rift sequences, including potential hydrocarbon plays analogous to those found in other conjugate South Atlantic basins.

The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located along the northeastern coast of Brazil, formed during the Mesozoic rifting of Gondwana, and is a prolific petroleum province known for its post-rift and pre-rift plays, including significant deepwater discoveries.

Cement stones are a rock that is predominantly constituted by diagenetically precipitated mineral cement, which infills pore spaces, binds detrital or biogenic components, and can form a significant portion of the rock fabric.

Flint is a cryptocrystalline sedimentary rock that is a variety of quartz (SiO2), typically dark grey to black, brown, or reddish-brown, and forms as nodules or concretions within chalk or limestone sequences.

Chalks are fine-grained carbonate materials that are primarily composed of the skeletal remains of calcareous nannofossils, particularly coccolithophores, and are characterized by their soft, friable, and poorly consolidated nature, often exhibiting high porosity and low strength.

3-esso-004-sps is a well that is a bore drilled into the Earth's subsurface for the purpose of exploring for or producing hydrocarbons, specifically targeting the deepwater carbonate reservoirs of the Brazilian Pre-Salt play.
A crack is a planar or curvilinear discontinuity within a rock mass that forms due to brittle deformation, often enhancing permeability in carbonate reservoirs.
Boundstone is a carbonate rock that consists of original components that were bound together *in situ* during deposition, typically by the growth of sessile organisms.

sb-2 is an exploration well that was drilled in the Santos Basin, offshore Brazil. It is a pioneering well that confirmed the presence of significant hydrocarbon accumulations within the Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs. This well provided critical data for the development of the Brazilian Pre-Salt play.

The Bonneville Basin is a paleolake basin that encompasses the maximum extent of the ancient Lake Bonneville, a large pluvial lake that existed in western North America during the Pleistocene epoch. It is characterized by extensive lacustrine deposits, relict shorelines, and the modern Bonneville Salt Flats, reflecting its past hydrological cycles.

CO2 is a fluid of the Earth that is a naturally occurring gas found in subsurface geological formations. It is often associated with hydrocarbon systems as a non-hydrocarbon component of reservoir fluids, particularly in the Brazilian Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

Magnesium smectite is a clay mineral that is a 2:1 phyllosilicate belonging to the smectite group, characterized by a high magnesium content in its octahedral sheet and exhibiting significant swelling properties upon hydration.

Ellimma longipectoralis is a fossil fish species that belongs to the extinct family †Ellimmichthyidae (Clupeiformes), characterized by its elongated pectoral fins and commonly found in Cretaceous deposits of Brazil.

Water is a fluid that is a chemical compound of hydrogen and oxygen (H2O), ubiquitous in the Earth's subsurface as formation water, connate water, or meteoric water, often coexisting with hydrocarbons in porous and permeable rock formations.

Wedging is a geological structure that describes the geometry of a rock unit or stratigraphic package. It is characterized by the progressive thinning of the unit to a sharp edge, often terminating against another geological feature or thinning out into a basin. This geometry commonly results from depositional processes, erosional truncation, or structural deformation, and is a key indicator in seismic interpretation for reservoir distribution.

An ostracod is a bivalved microcrustacean that possesses a chitinous or calcareous carapace and is widely preserved as a fossil in marine and non-marine sedimentary rocks, providing key data for biostratigraphy and paleoenvironmental analysis.

A playa-lake is a paleoenvironment that represents an ephemeral, shallow, and often saline or hypersaline lake in an arid or semi-arid closed basin. It is characterized by cycles of wetting and drying, leading to the deposition of evaporites, mudstones, and sometimes carbonates.
Mudrocks are sedimentary rocks that are predominantly composed of clay minerals and silt-sized particles, representing the lithified equivalent of mud.

Bivalve-gastropod is an invertebrate fossil assemblage that consists of the preserved remains of bivalve and gastropod mollusks. These fossils are commonly found in marine or lacustrine sedimentary successions and are significant for paleoenvironmental interpretation and biostratigraphic correlation.

Sphalerite is a rock that is predominantly composed of the mineral sphalerite, a zinc sulfide (ZnS), and typically forms in hydrothermal vein deposits or as a significant component in some sedimentary exhalative (SEDEX) or Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) ore bodies.
Svanbergite is a rock that is predominantly composed of the strontium aluminum phosphate sulfate mineral svanbergite, typically formed in altered sedimentary or metamorphic environments.

A zeolite rock is a rock that is predominantly composed of zeolite minerals, which are microporous aluminosilicate minerals commonly formed by the alteration of volcanic glass or other silicates in low-temperature diagenetic or hydrothermal environments.
Dolostones are sedimentary rocks that are predominantly composed of the mineral dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), typically formed through the diagenetic alteration of pre-existing limestones.

Microcrystalline is a texture that describes a rock or mineral aggregate where individual crystals are too small to be distinguished with the unaided eye, but are discernible under a petrographic microscope.

The Silurian is a geologic period that constitutes a major division of the Paleozoic Era, extending from the end of the Ordovician Period to the beginning of the Devonian Period, approximately spanning from 443.8 to 419.2 million years ago.
Magnesite is a mineral that is a trigonal magnesium carbonate (MgCO3), belonging to the calcite group, which commonly occurs as an alteration product of magnesium-rich rocks or in hydrothermal veins.

Magnesite is a mineral that is a magnesium carbonate (MgCO3) belonging to the calcite group, typically forming as a secondary mineral through the alteration of magnesium-rich rocks or by metasomatic replacement of limestones and dolomites.
Radiolaria is a type of marine microfossil that represents the preserved siliceous skeleton of a planktonic protozoan, serving as a key biostratigraphic marker in deep-marine sedimentary successions.

Zeolite is a mineral group that consists of microporous, aluminosilicate minerals characterized by a framework structure enclosing cavities occupied by large ions and water molecules, which can be released without major changes to the framework.

Bitumen is a naturally occurring organic material that is a highly viscous to solid mixture of complex hydrocarbons, typically black or dark brown, found in geological formations often as a product of petroleum alteration.

The Permian is a geologic period that constitutes the final period of the Paleozoic Era, spanning from approximately 298.9 to 251.9 million years ago, and is characterized by the assembly of the supercontinent Pangea and culminating in the largest mass extinction event in Earth's history.
Santonian Campanian is a chronostratigraphic interval that encompasses the Santonian and Campanian stages of the Late Cretaceous epoch, representing a significant period of Earth's history.

A continental-oceanic paleoenvironment is a transitional depositional setting that represents the dynamic interface between continental landmasses and oceanic basins, characterized by a complex interplay of terrestrial and marine processes, sediment sources, and environmental conditions.

Oolites are a type of fossil-associated carbonate particle that is characterized by spherical to subspherical shapes and concentric layers of calcium carbonate, typically less than 2 mm in diameter, precipitated around a nucleus.

A paleocontinent is a continent that existed in a geological past, whose configuration and position influenced global climate, ocean currents, and the distribution of paleoenvironments and life forms.

The Mesozoic is a chronostratigraphic unit of era rank that spans from approximately 252 to 66 million years ago, characterized by the breakup of Pangea, the dominance of dinosaurs, and the rifting and early sag phases of the South Atlantic opening, which facilitated the deposition of the Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

sb-e1 is a well that is drilled into the Earth's subsurface to explore for or produce hydrocarbons. It specifically targets geological formations, such as the carbonate reservoirs of the Brazilian Pre-Salt, to assess their potential or extract petroleum resources.
Shrubstone is a biogenic carbonate rock that exhibits a branching, arborescent, or shrub-like growth morphology, formed by the precipitation of carbonate minerals mediated by microbial communities.

Aragonite is a mineral that is a carbonate polymorph of calcite, having the chemical formula CaCO3 and crystallizing in the orthorhombic system. It is metastable at surface conditions and commonly inverts to calcite over geological time, often forming biogenic shells and early diagenetic cements.
A cobble is a rock fragment that is typically sub-rounded to rounded and has a diameter ranging from 64 mm to 256 mm, placing it between pebbles and boulders in the Udden-Wentworth grain size scale.
Pebbles are clastic sediment particles that range in diameter from 4 to 64 millimeters, typically exhibiting a rounded to sub-rounded shape due to transport and abrasion.
A cobble is a rock fragment that is typically sub-rounded to rounded and has a diameter ranging from 64 mm to 256 mm, placing it between pebbles and boulders in the Udden-Wentworth grain size scale.
The Furongian is a geological epoch that constitutes the third and final series of the Cambrian Period, spanning from approximately 497 to 485.4 million years ago.

A wavy physical structure is a geological structure that exhibits undulatory, curvilinear, or ripple-like patterns, often observed in bedding, laminae, or depositional surfaces within carbonate reservoirs, resulting from depositional processes or biological activity.

A coastal paleoenvironment is an ancient depositional environment that is situated at the interface between terrestrial and marine realms, characterized by the interplay of fluvial, tidal, and wave processes, and typically includes settings such as beaches, lagoons, estuaries, and deltas.

The Palaeozoic is a geological era that represents a major interval of Earth's history, spanning from approximately 541 to 252.2 million years ago, following the Neoproterozoic Era and preceding the Mesozoic Era.
Barite is a rock that is a consolidated aggregate of mineral grains predominantly composed of barium sulfate (BaSO4), characterized by its high specific gravity.

Mg claystones are a type of fine-grained siliciclastic sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of clay minerals and is intimately associated with microbialite carbonate successions, commonly occurring as interbeds or draping layers within the Brazilian Pre-Salt lacustrine depositional systems.
Dolomites are a type of carbonate rock that is predominantly composed of the mineral dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), typically formed through the diagenetic alteration of limestones or direct precipitation.

Mg-claystones are a fine-grained sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of clay-sized particles and contains a significant proportion of magnesium, typically within Mg-rich clay minerals such as sepiolite, palygorskite, or Mg-smectites.

The Kwanza Basin is a passive margin sedimentary basin that extends along the coast of Angola, formed during the breakup of Gondwana. It is characterized by a thick Mesozoic to Cenozoic sedimentary fill, including significant Pre-Salt and Post-Salt petroleum systems. This prolific hydrocarbon province is particularly known for its Aptian salt tectonics and associated traps.

The Palaeocene is a geological epoch that represents the earliest chronostratigraphic division of the Palaeogene Period and the Cenozoic Era. It spans from approximately 66 to 56 million years ago. This epoch immediately follows the Cretaceous Period and precedes the Eocene Epoch, marking the interval after the Cretaceous-Palaeogene extinction event.

A sandstone is a clastic sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of sand-sized mineral grains or rock fragments. These grains, typically quartz, feldspar, or lithic fragments, are cemented together by a matrix of finer material or chemical precipitates.

Eoaptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest part of the Aptian Stage, characterized in the Brazilian Pre-Salt by the deposition of the initial lacustrine carbonate successions.

The Santonian-Campanian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a specific interval within the Late Cretaceous epoch, spanning approximately from 86.3 to 72.1 million years ago. It is characterized by global sea-level fluctuations and, in the context of the Brazilian Pre-Salt, by the continued deposition of lacustrine and marine carbonate reservoirs during the post-rift sag phase.

3-brsa-1132-rjs is a well that is uniquely identified by the Brazilian National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (ANP) standard, drilled by Petrobras in the offshore Rio de Janeiro basin. It represents a specific bore drilled into the Earth's subsurface for the purpose of exploring or producing hydrocarbons.

Barra Velha Formations are a lithostratigraphic unit that comprises the main Aptian carbonate reservoir succession of the Brazilian Pre-Salt, characterized by microbial carbonates (e.g., stromatolites, thrombolites, oncolites) deposited in lacustrine environments.

9-brsa-1212-rjs is a well that is an artificial bore drilled into the Earth's crust for the exploration or production of hydrocarbons. "3-brsa-1212-rjs" is a well that is an exploratory or appraisal borehole drilled in the Brazilian offshore, identified by the official ANP designation system. Profundal is a paleoenvironment that represents the deep-water zone of a lake or ocean basin, situated below the photic zone where light penetration is insufficient for photosynthesis. It is characterized by low energy conditions, fine-grained sedimentation, and specific faunal assemblages adapted to dark, cold, and often anoxic conditions. In Pre-Salt carbonate systems, this setting is associated with the accumulation of fine-grained microbialites or pelagic sediments in the deeper parts of the basin.

A marl paleoenvironment is a depositional setting that is characterized by the accumulation of mixed carbonate and siliciclastic muds, typically in low-energy, often restricted marine or lacustrine conditions.
A ridge-type structure is a physical structure that is characterized by an elongated, elevated morphology, often forming a topographic high relative to surrounding areas.
A fissure ridge is a linear geological edifice that forms along a crustal fracture or fissure, resulting from the eruption of magma or the precipitation of minerals from hydrothermal fluids.

Gases are a fluid phase that exists in the subsurface, typically composed of hydrocarbons (e.g., methane, ethane) and non-hydrocarbon components (e.g., CO2, N2, H2S), characterized by low viscosity and high compressibility, and often found trapped within porous reservoir rocks.
The Paleocene is a geological epoch that represents the first epoch of the Paleogene Period and the Cenozoic Era, spanning from approximately 66 to 56 million years ago.
Upper Cretaceous is a subdivision of the Cretaceous Period that represents the later part of this geological time interval, spanning from approximately 100.5 to 66 million years ago.

A Bacia do Espírito Santo is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore southeastern Brazil, formed during the Mesozoic rifting and subsequent opening of the South Atlantic Ocean, and characterized by a thick sedimentary infill comprising pre-salt and post-salt sequences with proven hydrocarbon accumulations.

Aptian Alagoas is a chronostratigraphic substage that represents the upper part of the Aptian Stage in the Brazilian Pre-Salt basins. It is characterized by the widespread deposition of the evaporitic succession, including halite, anhydrite, and potassium salts, which overlie the main lacustrine carbonate reservoirs. This unit marks a period of restricted marine conditions and high evaporation rates.

Gneiss is a metamorphic rock that exhibits a coarse-grained, foliated texture (gneissic banding) characterized by alternating layers of light-colored felsic minerals and dark-colored mafic minerals, formed under high-grade metamorphic conditions.

The Holocene is a geological epoch that represents the current interglacial period, following the Last Glacial Period of the Pleistocene Epoch, and spans from approximately 11,700 years ago to the present day.

Tithonian is a geological age that constitutes the uppermost stage of the Late Jurassic Epoch, spanning from approximately 152.1 to 145 million years ago and immediately preceding the Berriasian Stage of the Early Cretaceous.
Mudrocks are a type of sedimentary rock that are fine-grained, composed predominantly of clay minerals and silt-sized particles, and formed from the compaction and cementation of mud.

The Santos Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore southeastern Brazil, extending along the continental margin from the northern coast of Rio de Janeiro to the southern coast of Santa Catarina. It is a major petroleum province, hosting significant hydrocarbon accumulations, particularly the giant Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

The Quaternary is a geological period and chronostratigraphic unit that represents the most recent interval of Earth's history, extending from 2.58 million years ago to the present day, and is characterized by significant climatic oscillations and the evolution of modern human species.

An igneous paleoenvironment is a paleoenvironment that is characterized by active magmatism and volcanism, leading to the formation of igneous rocks and influencing the depositional setting through heat flow, topography, and material supply.

Zircon is a mineral that is a zirconium silicate (ZrSiO4) commonly found as an accessory component in igneous and metamorphic rocks, characterized by its high durability and resistance to weathering. Its ability to incorporate trace amounts of uranium and thorium makes it an invaluable tool for U-Pb radiometric dating and provenance studies.

Ostracodes are a group of small bivalved crustaceans that are preserved as microfossils, characterized by a calcified, hinged carapace enclosing the body. They are abundant in both marine and freshwater sedimentary rocks, serving as key biostratigraphic markers and paleoenvironmental indicators, particularly in the context of lacustrine and marine carbonate systems like the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

A Bacia de Sergipe-Alagoas is a sedimentary basin that is located on the northeastern coast of Brazil, formed during the Mesozoic rifting and opening of the South Atlantic Ocean. It is a prolific petroleum province, characterized by pre-rift, syn-rift, and post-rift sequences, containing significant hydrocarbon accumulations in both shallow and deepwater settings.
A calcimudstone is a carbonate rock that is mud-supported, containing less than 10% allochems, and primarily composed of micrite.
Cleavage is a secondary planar fabric that develops in rocks due to tectonic deformation, allowing the rock to split preferentially along these planes.

Early Mississippian is a chronostratigraphic subdivision that encompasses the earliest interval of the Mississippian Period, representing the lower part of this subperiod within the Carboniferous System.

Pennsylvanian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a subperiod of the Carboniferous Period, spanning from approximately 323.2 to 298.9 million years ago, and is characterized by extensive coal deposits, significant glaciations, and the diversification of terrestrial flora and fauna, including early reptiles.

A carbonate mound is a type of rock accumulation that is primarily composed of carbonate minerals, often formed by microbial activity (e.g., stromatolites, thrombolites) and early diagenetic cementation. It typically lacks a rigid framework and exhibits a mounded to columnar geometry, commonly found in lacustrine environments such as the Brazilian Pre-Salt.

3-brsa-1310-rjs is an oil and gas well that is uniquely identified by the ANP (Agência Nacional do Petróleo, Gás Natural e Biocombustíveis) designation '3-brsa-1310-rjs' and drilled for the exploration or production of hydrocarbons in the Brazilian offshore, specifically within the Rio de Janeiro state's jurisdictional area.

3-brsa-1267a-rjs is an exploration well that was drilled by Petrobras in the Santos Basin, offshore Brazil, to investigate and evaluate hydrocarbon potential, specifically targeting the carbonate reservoirs of the Pre-Salt sequence.
Limestone is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), typically formed from the accumulation of skeletal fragments of marine organisms or by chemical precipitation.

The Archean is a geological eon that spans from approximately 4.0 to 2.5 billion years ago, characterized by the formation of the Earth's first stable continental crust and the emergence of early prokaryotic life.

Neoaptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the upper substage of the Aptian Stage within the Lower Cretaceous Series. It spans a specific interval of geological time, following the Bedoulian and preceding the Albian, and is characterized by distinct biostratigraphic markers.

Intra-Albian is a chronostratigraphic interval that occurs entirely within the Albian Age, representing the specific time during which geological processes, such as the deposition and diagenesis of lacustrine carbonate reservoirs, took place in the Brazilian Pre-Salt basins.

The Pelotas Basin is a passive margin sedimentary basin that is located offshore southern Brazil and Uruguay. It formed during the Mesozoic breakup of Gondwana and is characterized by a thick Cenozoic and Mesozoic sedimentary infill with potential for hydrocarbon accumulation.

Yacoraite is an evaporite rock that is primarily composed of the rare hydrated calcium sulfate mineral yacoraite, characterized by the chemical formula Ca5(SO4)2(OH)6·H2O, and typically formed in hypersaline depositional environments.

A Bacia de Salta Argentina is a sedimentary basin that is an intracratonic rift basin located in northwestern Argentina, characterized by Mesozoic syn-rift and post-rift sequences with significant hydrocarbon potential.
A Campanian-Turonian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a geological time interval encompassing the Turonian, Coniacian, Santonian, and Campanian stages of the Late Cretaceous epoch.
Diabase is a mafic igneous rock that is characterized by a fine- to medium-grained texture, often ophitic or subophitic, and typically occurs as shallow intrusive dikes and sills.

Basalt is an igneous rock composed of minerals that is dark-colored, fine-grained, and mafic, primarily consisting of plagioclase, pyroxene, and often olivine, formed from the rapid cooling of lava at or near the Earth's surface.
An intra-Barremian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents a time interval occurring entirely within the Barremian Age.
The Eocene is a geological epoch that constitutes the second epoch of the Paleogene Period, spanning from approximately 56 to 33.9 million years ago.
A fold is a deformational structure that results from the ductile bending or buckling of rock layers due to compressive stress.

Granitic rock is an igneous rock that is characterized by a phaneritic (coarse-grained) texture and a felsic composition, primarily consisting of quartz, feldspar, and micas, typically formed from the slow cooling of magma deep within the Earth's crust.

The Barra Velha Formation is a lithostratigraphic unit that constitutes the primary lacustrine carbonate reservoir interval within the Brazilian Pre-Salt succession. It is characterized by microbialite-dominated carbonates, including stromatolites and other biogenic/abiogenic precipitates, deposited during the rift-sag transition phase of the South Atlantic opening.

Fractures are planar geological structures that represent a break in the rock mass, typically with negligible to minor displacement, resulting from stress exceeding rock strength. They can significantly impact reservoir permeability and porosity, acting as conduits or barriers for fluid flow, particularly within Pre-Salt carbonate reservoirs.

Bacia de Pelotas is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore southern Brazil and Uruguay, formed during the Mesozoic breakup of Gondwana. It is characterized by a thick Cenozoic siliciclastic infill deposited in a passive margin setting.

Basement is a lithological unit that comprises the crystalline igneous and metamorphic rocks forming the crust beneath a sedimentary cover, often serving as the structural or economic base for hydrocarbon exploration.

The Campos Basin is a sedimentary basin that is located offshore southeastern Brazil, characterized by a thick Mesozoic to Cenozoic sedimentary infill developed during the Gondwana breakup and subsequent passive margin evolution.

Halite is a chemical sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of the mineral sodium chloride (NaCl), forming through the precipitation of salts from evaporating saline waters in arid environments.

The Eocene is a geological epoch that represents the second epoch of the Paleogene Period within the Cenozoic Era, spanning from approximately 56 to 33.9 million years ago, and is characterized by a warm global climate and the significant diversification of modern mammalian orders.
Eoaptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that constitutes the earliest subdivision of the Aptian Stage of the Early Cretaceous Epoch.

Grupo Guaratiba is a lithostratigraphic unit of Group rank that comprises the Pre-Salt succession in the Santos Basin, characterized by lacustrine carbonates, siliciclastics, and volcanic rocks deposited during the rift and sag phases of the South Atlantic opening.

Neocomian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest part of the Early Cretaceous epoch. It encompasses the Berriasian, Valanginian, and Hauterivian stages, spanning from approximately 145 to 133 million years ago.

Neo-Barremian-Eo-Aptian is a chronostratigraphic unit that spans the late Barremian to early Aptian stages of the Early Cretaceous. It represents a critical geological time interval during which the sag-phase lacustrine carbonate reservoirs of the Brazilian Pre-Salt were extensively deposited, characterized by widespread anoxic conditions and the development of microbialite and coquina facies.

Intra-Alagoas is a chronostratigraphic interval that occurs within the Alagoas Stage, representing a specific period of deposition and geological events during the Aptian in the Brazilian marginal basins, particularly relevant for Pre-Salt carbonate reservoir development.

A carbonate rock is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of carbonate minerals, such as calcite or dolomite, and commonly forms through biogenic or chemical processes in marine or lacustrine settings.

Gypsum is an evaporite rock that is primarily composed of the mineral gypsum (hydrous calcium sulfate, CaSO₄·2H₂O), typically forming in restricted marine or lacustrine environments through the evaporation of water.
A marine paleoenvironment is a paleoenvironment that is characterized by the presence of seawater and the deposition of sediments under its influence, typically supporting marine flora and fauna.

A Tethyan chronostratigraphic unit is a body of rock that was deposited during the Mesozoic Era, characterized by fossil assemblages and lithofacies indicative of the Tethys Ocean paleobiogeographic realm.
Cenomanian is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the earliest stage of the Late Cretaceous Epoch, spanning from approximately 100.5 to 93.9 million years ago.

Halite is a chemical sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of the mineral sodium chloride (NaCl), forming through the precipitation of salts from evaporating saline waters in arid environments.

The Itapema Formation is a lithostratigraphic unit that constitutes the basal lacustrine carbonate succession of the Brazilian Pre-Salt sequence in the Santos and Campos Basins. It is characterized by microbialites, including stromatolites and thrombolites, deposited in shallow, often hypersaline, lacustrine environments. This formation represents a significant reservoir interval within the Pre-Salt play.

A littoral paleoenvironment is a depositional environment that represents the ancient coastal zone, situated at the interface between a terrestrial setting and a body of water, where sedimentation is influenced by wave action, tides, or lake-level fluctuations.

A continental paleoenvironment is a paleoenvironment that is characterized by depositional settings on land, away from direct marine influence. It encompasses a variety of environments such as lacustrine, fluvial, eolian, and alluvial fan systems, and in the Brazilian Pre-Salt, it primarily refers to the extensive lacustrine systems where microbial carbonate factories thrived.

Aptian Superior is a chronostratigraphic unit that represents the upper interval of the Aptian Stage, spanning a specific geological time period within the Early Cretaceous. It is particularly significant in the Brazilian Pre-Salt for its association with the deposition of major carbonate reservoir rocks.

Calcarenites are a type of limestone that is characterized by a clastic texture and composed predominantly of sand-sized (0.0625 to 2 mm) carbonate grains, such as bioclasts, ooids, peloids, or intraclasts.

A siltite is a sedimentary rock that is primarily composed of silt-sized particles, ranging from 0.004 to 0.0625 mm in diameter. It is a clastic rock, typically formed from the accumulation and lithification of detrital grains such as quartz, feldspar, and clay minerals, and represents a finer-grained equivalent of sandstone.
A bioclast is a fragment that is derived from the skeletal or shell material of an organism, often fossilized, and serves as a constituent grain in sedimentary rocks, particularly carbonates.
Dolostone is a sedimentary carbonate rock that is predominantly composed of the mineral dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), typically containing more than 50% dolomite by weight.
Siltstone is a clastic sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of silt-sized particles, which are finer than sand but coarser than clay.
Bioclasts are skeletal fragments that are derived from the remains of organisms and are preserved as fossil components within sedimentary rocks.
A calcarenite is a limestone that is primarily composed of sand-sized (0.0625 to 2 mm) carbonate grains.

A ripple is a sedimentary bedform that is a small-scale undulation of the sediment surface, typically characterized by a wavelength of centimeters to decimeters and formed by the interaction of a fluid (water or wind) with unconsolidated sediment.

A Barra Velha Formation Field is an oil and gas field that extracts hydrocarbons primarily from the Barra Velha Formation, a significant lacustrine carbonate reservoir unit within the Brazilian Pre-Salt play.

A coquina is a type of bioclastic sedimentary rock that is predominantly composed of whole or fragmented shells of bivalve mollusks, often with a minor matrix. In the Brazilian Pre-Salt, these rocks are typically lacustrine in origin and constitute significant carbonate reservoirs.

Campos de Badejo is an oil and gas field that is situated in the Campos Basin, offshore Brazil, and primarily produces hydrocarbons from turbiditic sandstone reservoirs of the Oligocene Carapebus Formation.

Mangakahia is a genus of foraminifera that is characterized by a distinctive calcareous test morphology. This microfossil is commonly found in marine sedimentary rocks and is utilized in biostratigraphic correlation and paleoenvironmental reconstruction, particularly in petroleum exploration.

An ostracod is a biomineralized microfossil that is primarily composed of calcium carbonate, forming the bivalved carapace of a small aquatic crustacean, and is a common constituent of carbonate rocks.

A spherulite stone is a rock that is characterized by the presence of spherulites, which are spherical to subspherical aggregates of radially arranged acicular crystals, typically composed of carbonate minerals like aragonite or calcite. These structures commonly form during early diagenesis or direct precipitation in lacustrine or shallow marine environments.

Oxfordian is a chronostratigraphic unit that constitutes a stage within the Late Jurassic epoch, spanning from approximately 163.5 to 157.3 million years ago.
